newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian lawmakers vote to elect president.
newsitem.headline: Indian lawmakers vote to elect president.

text.p: Members of an electoral college began voting on Monday to choose India's tenth president in a virtual one-horse race that was expected to pick K.R. Narayanan, currently the vice-president.
Officials said elected lawmakers of the federal parliament and state legislatures were voting in a secret ballot across the nation through a system of proportional representation.
The electoral college has 4,848 members. Counting of votes and the announcement of the result are scheduled for July 17.
The new president, scheduled to assume office for a five-year term later this month, will take charge three weeks before the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain on August 15.

Traditionally seen as a rubber-stamp job, the post of the president, India's constitutional head, has been seen as crucial following the emergence of coalition politics in which the president plays a key role in government formation.
President Shankar Dayal Sharma's five-year term expires on July 25. Though eligible for a second term, Sharma did not seek re-election.
If elected, Narayanan would become India's first low-caste president emerging from a traditional Hindu social hierarchy.

Narayanan, a former diplomat who was born in a poor family, was being contested by former chief election commissioner T.N. Seshan, but his victory was considered assured after three leading political groups pledged their support to him.
The 76-year-old Narayanan has received backing from Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral's United Front coalition, the Congress party and the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).
The main support for Seshan is from the regional Hindu Shiv Sena party.
During his five-year term until 1996 as chief election commissioner, Seshan targeted politicians and bureaucrats in a campaign to clean up electoral politics.
